reviewText:
Early Access Review

I was going to write up an elegant summary of the game but honestly it doesn't need it. The game is easily the best golf sim I've played. The fact it has an unblievable course creator just puts it over the top. It's intuitive, fun and beautiful. You can play your course as your build it to ensure its exactly what you wanted. From placing objects such as buildings, trees, signs to sculpting a simple sand trap, you'll be in love with the ease at which it's all done.

Ontop of that the game is gorgeous to look at, runs great and simply the best representation of golf you can find on PC. With an interesting multiplayer aspect you can challenge your friends or take on their ghost ball of their best score.

So if you like golf, or golf creation and horribly written reviews, you should get this game.

reviewText: What an utter disappointment for a game with so much potential and practically zero competition on the PC market. Very limited PC graphics optimization and horrible performance issues prevent me from recommending this game in its current state. With wonky putting, an unreliable swing mechanic, and lackluster ball physics (seriously the same bounce on every terrain except sand), you'd best save your money until this is patched.\n\nOn the plus side the sound design is top notch and the course creator is a great feature, however its certainly not enough to justify buying a game that feels like its still in beta.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

From what I have played so far, this might be one of the best golf games ever made and it is nice to finally see a game like this on Steam.

The golf course creation tool is amazing.  You are able to create and customize your own golf course - It can be fully randomly generated or you can hand craft all of the holes, bunkers, trees, hills, anything you could think of, and you can share it to the public.

As it is currently Early Access some game modes are not available as of yet, such as Tour's and Tournaments (These have a coming soon sign).  Stat tracking is also on the way.

As far as I can see, there is no online multiplayer, however you do get to play against other players ghosts and The Golf Club supports local Multiplayer.

Graphics wise - Very good, very nice looking game.

Audio is also nice and the commentary that is in the game is a little different from games such as EA's  Tiger Woods games, and that is a nice change.

reviewText:
Usually when I look at a game, if it has mixed or below reviews I steer clear.  Luckily I got The Golf Club before it got too negative, because I personally have never had any issues with the performance of the game.  I don't doubt those who say they have, but I have had nothing but fun playing this game.

On the hardware side, my PC has an i5, and a GTX760, and the game runs very smoothly, with the exception of the rare course with massive amounts of trees.

As far as content, well, you play golf.  Some people appear unhappy that there is no career mode, and while that would be cool, it wasn't part of the game I bought, and my family enjoys just sitting down for a round of golf when we get together.  I guess a lot of people are looking for a replacement for their previous favorite golf sims, and they find The Golf Club lacking, but if all you want is to play a round of golf when you feel like a round of golf, then this fits the bill nicely.

reviewText:
This was a hugely anticipated game for an alternative for the other (dying) golf series and a game finally on PC.  While the game initially fills void and you can play some video golf , it becomes increasingly frustrating the more you play it.

The user created courses are the heart of the game and it's fun to play others creations.   This is best part of the game.  Course difficulties and ratings help you find what you're looking for.  I love this part of the game and applaud the effort that a lot of users make on some truly creative courses.

As I put hours into the game my frustration level with wind and putting has increased to the point where I can't even finish a round.  It gets boring and repetitive.  Long drive, approach misses because wind is inconsistent, and 2-3 putts because the putting is next to impossible.  Approach shots become increasing difficult if you don't need a 100% shot.  I've played the other series for years and never had even close to this much difficulty.

If any game needs a putt preview, it's this one.   The touch" required on putts took awhile to learn

reviewText:
I have never played a game as much as I have with The Golf Club. The Greg Norman Course designer is incredibly powerful, easy to use, and will have you creating fantastic courses in no time. The actual golf is great, relying on skill and not special pants you can buy that help you hit it 20 yards further. The career mode in the game is the only downside of the game, but if you head on over to TGCTours.com, you can play a REAL career mode with real players (check it out)!

The community on the HB Forums and TGCTours.com is incredibly active, helpful and fun, which further makes this game a complete joy to play. HB Studios is always making tweaks, and adding new features and themes for courses to help improve the game even more.

100% recommended to any golf fans and aspiring course designers.

reviewText:
First off, while this is marked as a recommended title, there are issues to be aware of.

This game is fun, but it's missing some key elements that sports type games need to be an overall good experience. There is nothing in the way of a practice mode, or even a basic tutorial. You're thrust into the game, and left to figure out how to play on your own. I don't understand why there was such an oversight in this design, and the developers even acknowledge the lack of a practice/tutorial mode in a video on their own page.

That being said, it is great fun. The courses, while not real world copies, are challenging, and quite rewarding to those that take risks in their shots. The game mechanics are good, and the game is engrossing enough to have you looking for you club, when you've missed a shot by inches, and decide to throw it.

The bad is this. I felt like I've played this game before, at least, I've played PGA Golf Games before, but they felt like there was more to it. This feels less than, because it's more simulator, and less casual. Putting is challenging, and there aren't 15 different types of overlays setup for you to use. Instead you get a grid, and a camera you can move. It feels basic, but it's more challenging in the end.

If that is what the devs were going for, which I believe they were, then they hit the mark. This is not a Tiger Woods game, this is a Golf Simulator, rage included at no extra charge.

p.s. please add some sort of practice or tutorial modes. That's really a rookie mistake.

reviewText:
I don't get too wound up about my golf game, and it's a good thing I don't. Otherwise, long ago I would have thrown myself in the nearest water hazard along with my clubs. Enjoying a nice day on a gorgeous course is enough. The Golf Club captures this essence in both the challenge of perfecting your swing and the pride of being able to create your own gorgeous courses. But, is that beauty enough?

The game's course creation tools are impressive in their ability to not only let you build detailed courses, but the scalability of the tools themselves. You can apply some macro-levels rules to shape your course with simple min/max sliders – like if you want your course as a whole to be hilly or have lots of water – or dive into placing individual trees, objects, and even whales. The menu presentation is straightforward, but there are times like placing water, for instance, where the macro and micro tools can cause confusion on how to exactly get what you want. Regardless, the game puts a lot of power in your hands, and with a little tinkering you soon learn how to efficiently work with the tools and start making some sweet courses.

I was really impressed with the naturally adaptability of your holes in the broader context of the world's environment. Moving a hole en masse, rearranging holes' order, adding/subtracting holes, and even switching out the overall theme of the environment (you can choose from desert, autumn/forest, rural, alpine, and the wild Scotland-like links terrain) is well done.

You can also dive in and playtest your hole at any time; dropping your ball in a specific location or playing the whole thing. Finding and playing other people's creations is easy as well, and you can use them to put together your own tour of courses.

The golf gameplay itself is challenging and satisfying. The right analog swing requires precision, especially when applying draw or fade, and a minimal pre-swing HUD is hard at first. Gauging your swing power while putting, in particular, takes getting used to, but it won't take long to develop a rhythm and feel to your swing.

As well-crafted as the game is, it's missing a sense of progression that drives you forward. While creating the course of your dreams (or someone else's nightmares) feels good, I missed a larger structure. Visual or physical golfer upgrades, an overarching rewards system tied to your stats, or even a career shell are missing and there's lost momentum within the game because of it. Seeing what kinds of courses I and others could come up with and the challenges therein is motivating, but the sustenance it provides is impermanent.

The Golf Club delivers as a course creator, and it's no slouch swinging the clubs, either. What's missing is the personality: the larger career structure and personal investment in your avatar to spur players on and elevate the experience from a nice set of features to the complete package   9/10


Appsy doodles

reviewText: When I bought this game, their FAQ said they were still considering incorporating a 3-click shot meter, which I assumed would be optional.  I understood they wanted a 'realistic' mechanism to focus on the 'feel' of golf, but I hoped, because of their FAQ, that they would add the 3-click shot meter for those people who preferred a lighter fun vs super serious.  Eventually they dug their feet in the ground and decided they wanted 'realism,' which completely killed my desire to play the game.  While it seems their mechanism for a console game controller works okay, their mouse and keyboard mechanism is too frustrating and imprecise to be fun.  At least for me (some may disagree).\nConsequentially, I felt like I had wasted my money, which inspired this less than positive review.  Alternatively, if Steam allowed (easier) refunds, I would have done so, and would not have been as frustrated, and would have just waited for a golf game that is more accommodating to us 'less-serious' golfers.

reviewText:
This game is turning into a solid golf game, the graphics are great to look at and the gameplay is getting there IMO. The main selling point of this game for me is the GNCD, the course designer. I have spent many hours on this and once you get the hang of it, your only limited by your imagination.
This is a worthy successor to the EA TW series and plays a lot like it too, well if you consider that most of the people that worked on that game are the ones that developed TGC. The good thing about this game is the fact that the developers are still working on it and fixing bugs and adding stuff to it all the time, once it’s finished then this will be a solid and enjoyable title for everyone to play.
The only real problem with this game for me is the graphics issue if you own an AMD Radeon card, especially the newer models, but I think this is more to do with the Unity engine than anything else, as playing this game with an Nvidia card seems less problematic and appears to run better.
Although this game has been developed for the PC it still very much feels like a port, as its main focus IMO is for the console market, after all that’s where the money is.
Anyway, if you’re in any doubt about buying this game, then I would recommend you do, especially if you like golf and have been looking for a worthy successor to EA TW series. There are also more updates coming soon, and with the number of courses made by the community, then its longevity is assured. It’s not quite the golf sim this has been hailed to be, as that title I think belongs to another game currently in development.
Anyway this is money well spent on.

Update:
I can't believe that this game has now been out for over 20 months, it has had a lot of fixes applied to it and it certainly has improved since its early access days. Graphics wise this game is great to look at and I can’t fault it on that front, however the gameplay is a lot easier than it used to be IMO, it’s easier to hit straighter shots and plays more like an arcade game rather than an actual golf sim, even with all the aid’s turned off. This game still suffers with issues, originally with AMD cards and then with Nvidia cards, although fixes have been applied to fix the Nvidia issues, I wish the same could be said for AMD users, anyway putting those glitches aside, this is still a great game and I would still rate this up there with the likes of EA TW series. The games real selling point for me has been and will always be the Greg Normal Course Designer and the thousands of community designed courses out there, some of course (no pun intended) better than others. And the great thing about it is that they are all free to play, let’s hope that this stays that way.
Player customisation has been cranked up and the variety of shirts and trousers available to dress your player up has increased, but I would like to see more with also some community made ones thrown in too. The selection of golf clubs has not changed and I believe that this is something that could certainly be improved along with the option to hit shots with more back spin etc.
If your looking for a game to play against AI, then you'll be dissapointed, although you can play against the ghost" of other players who have played the courses

reviewText:
Great golf sim with a few quirks.

I love this game - play it several times a week with my Dad. I'd definitely recommend it to anyone who wants a good solid golf game, but it's certainly not perfect. Probably easiest to sum up with a list of pros and cons:

Pros
The core of the game is rock solid and realistic. The feel of the swing, the look of the courses, the physics, and the action of the ball are all great.
Fantastic course editor - best I've ever seen in a golf game. You can play courses created by other palyers or generate a fresh new course with just a few clicks. You'll certainly never run out of courses to play. Very satisfying when you put in a good round because you know you earned it. :)
Skill is not stat based. If your get better at the game it's because you've learned to play better.
Devs are still improving the game. I've been playing since the first day of Early Access and the Devs have been communicating and responding - while still sticking to their gameplan. They haven't fixed all the quirks, but the game has seen steady improvements over the months.
Cons
Some machines might struggle with the graphics. Seems to recquire more CPU/GPU power than you might think. Only a few graphics settings to adjust.
The swing controls can be hard to learn. I love the controls (I use xbox 360 controller) but some people seem to get frustrated. No option for the old 'three-click' method that is popular in other games. I think this is part of the 'level playing field' that the devs are shooting for. They have worked hard to make the competition skill-based and fair.
The interface is sometimes clunky. All the info and controls are there, but sometimes they are not intuitive.  Took me a long time to figure out what the two different distances on the putting green were (one is distance to the cup, and the other is the distance to your aiming marker). I still can't figure out how to properly show an instant replay. :)
No career mode or similar extra features. The Tiger Woods games were full of all sorts of extras and some people might expect them here. Presentation is somewhat sparse. The voicover/commenter is well done, but there is very little 'juice' or graphical embellishments to spice things up.
For me the pros definitely outweigh the cons. This is one of my most played games of 2014 and I expect it will be in 2015, too.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Looks good and plays good.

It's not the easiest of golf games (I've probably only managed 1 under par score in 8+ hours) but I'd rather it be that way. If I found it too easy I'd probably get a bit bored of it.

The course creator is fantastic and so easy to use.

In all the time I've played so far I think I've only played a couple of the developers courses twice, everything else I've just had one round on. There's so many courses to choose from, you'll always be able to find something new to play.

Highly recommended if you like golf games (and it's still in Early Access with more stuff to come).
voteText: 18 of 24 people (75%) found this review helpful

reviewText: This is a great golf game. There are many golf games out there, however they lack in the PC world. The overall feel of this game -- as far as the gameplay and layout of the game goes -- is really quite astonishing. Unlike a lot of games, with this game you have to take everything into account from the wind, speed of the fairways/greens, slope of the holes, etc. It really is a very neurotic game and you have to be smart how you play it. On a difficulty perspective, this game is very challenging. It takes lots of practice on each course to master it. It's almost like actually golfing where you have to take notes, make adjustments, and eat it when you fail. I highly recommend getting this game if you're an avid golf fan like I am.
voteText: 13 of 15 people (87%) found this review helpful 2 people found this review funny

reviewText:
I've had my eye on this game for quite some time. I picked it up during a sale recently and do not regret it at all.

I'm a former Links player and I've been looking for a simliar experience for quite some time. This game captures that experience. I'm not a big fan of the Tiger Woods gaming experience. The RPG elements and monetization scheme is just not for me.

This game is about skill and consistency. There is a learning curve. You'll be frustrated and challenged. There is no magic win button/skill/purchase. There is just you and your skill. As it should be. Trust me, I'm right up against that learning curve with only a few hours in. Out of the gate, this game feels good. Tons of potential here.

There are pretty consistent updates to the game and content additions. The community is growing and getting stronger. Support this game if you are a fan of games of skill, rather than a vapid pay to win environment.

It isn't without a few bugaboos. Nothing has been a show stopper, up to this point.

On thing that I wish they would add is some sort of visual indicator of your swing.

reviewText:
Seems all my game reviews were removed so heres another try...

The Golf Club is  primarily a golf simulator with an outstanding and easy to use course creator.

While it lacks a conventional career mode and officially licenced courses, the high quality of many user created courses and competitive play via tournaments that mimic the pro circuit from the dedicated folks at tgctours.com , more than makes up for it.

The game is still being updated even though it has been out of early access for some time now. All but one of the updates are free and add value to what is already a great game.

The Devs since day one of EA have always been involved with the community and continue to listen to feedback from players.

Highly recommended for the golf enthusiast or those with a creative flair.

reviewText:
There is a huge lack of golf sims out there - remember Microsoft Golf, Arnold Palmer Links, and of course Tiger Woods? Now there are basically The Golf Club and WGT. And between the two, I'll take The Golf Club any day.

The graphics are good - I won't say GREAT - and the sounds/speech is good (although the commentator gets a bit annoying after a bit). Mechanics are solid, certainly better than the ridiculous 2 click meter used in WGT. If you like real swing method using your mouse, rather than clicking on a meter, TGC is for you. It doesn't quite rise to the level of the swing meter on Tiger Woods - which I consider to be the best golf game ever - but it's not too far off. All in all, you can play 18 (or 9) holes and have a darned enjoyable time; for true golf enthusiasts, this is probably as close to the real thing as you can get without lugging your clubs out to the local links.

A few negatives: the match-making. NOT easy to jump into a multi-player game against real people. The menus are not very easy to navigate, despite their initial appearance with large labelled icons. You have to click and click and click to find a course to play, set up the paramaters and match type and difficulty, then when trying to find opponents to play TGC will automatically locate players" and fill your roster to the number you have selected (2

reviewText: Golf.  Straight up.  I haven't found anything any closer in a video game to a real life round.   I laugh, I cry I hold my breath, I shout, and most importantly (for any great game) I rage quit from time to time, haha!   The Golf Club is a gem!  Great for both the casual player as well as anyone who wants to get competitive with it (see TGC Tours)!  The entertainment value of this game is off the charts, if you're a golf fan you'd be doing yourself a disservice to not pick up this steal of a deal!!   Not to mention the amazing support from the dev team who are listening to the players and making this game better all the time!  Cheers!

reviewText:
The graphics are nice, but this just isn't a good golf game compared to other available PC golf games (such as Customplay 2010 or Hank Haney's World Golf- which both use the same basic golf engine and both having comparable realism to The Golf Club).  Too much is missing in terms of gameplay and game types (there are no skins or stableford games), and overall this feels like a rushed console port.  The mouse swing never feels right, and is extremely unforgiving.   While the random course generator is a nice feature, the editor itself is tedious to use and not as powerful as the editors featured in other golf games (such as the Links or Jack Nicklaus series).

Do yourself a favor and avoid purchasing this game.

reviewText:
The Golf Club is by far the best game I've ever played.    The gameplay,   and the course creator will keep this game growing for years to come.   There are some incredible course designers that put courses out on a daily basis so the replay value here is crazy good.    The devs are quick to fix things and add new features but they're a small team so you have to be patient.     The game has grown leaps and bounds within the last year and it's light years better than some of the current competiton in my opinion.

A few cons is that they really need to work on the social aspect of the game so that it's easier to find multiplayer games.  They are lacking typical gamemodes that you expect to see and they don't and will never have a conventional lobby.   They basically just have you send an invite to a friend to join you a the course but only half the time it works.  You are constantly having to kick your friend from the game and re add him to just see him play.    Like I said,  it's still the best game I've played but the multi player taking a backseat to some of the other features has always left me scratching my head..

The course creator is revolutionairy,  it's just flat out amazing.   This game appeals more to the guy that wants a relaxing real round of golf without all the EA sports glitz and glamour.   This game can be played with a controller,  PS4 is what I use..  I own the game on my ps4 and PC,  and I get all the updates on my PC as soon as they're ready which is awesome.  Honestly though,  the game plays just as well on the ps4.  It seems to me that they've taken lots of time to optizimze it for the consoles and I can certainly undertand why considering that is the majority of their audience.

I give this game maximum stars, even with it's issues...   Also,  if you play the a course insipred by the Delta Theme"   I was the guy that named that theme!!!  I won a "name that theme"  competition and the boys from HBS sent me some cool swagg for my winning submission.

One of the big fish up at the golf club name is Anthony Kyne
date: and he is a very likable chap
recommended: who does live streams often where he takes questions from us mere mortals...  I have grown fond of Anthony over the last year and have his face tattooted on my buttocks ;)\n"

reviewText: I've been looking for a good golf game for the PC for a while now (The TW series doesn't count) and I caught this on a steam sale.  Been playing it for a while in early access and have enjoyed it immensely.  Now that the game's out, I have mixed feelings about it.  On one hand, the mechanics of the swing (I play with an xbox controller) are good and the way the ball reacts to the environment is very good.  However, something about it just seems rushed and unfinished.  I'll get hours upon hours of enjoyment out of it and hopefully it gets improved down the line because it's a good game, with the chance to be great.  Would definitely recommend to any golf fan, but it may not appeal to everybody because of the rough edges to it.

reviewText:
Being a avid golfer in real life playing of an +2 handicap myself I have played most of the golf games out there. And to be honest most of them become boring because they are way to easy to master. The golf club however always seems to have a new challenge up its sleeve.

I have read many reviews slamming the inconsistency of playing with your mouse. My experience is that yes it is challenging but fair. I have played and struggled but learned with each round (Pro Tip, get yourself a proper mouse and a good gaming mouse pad I recommend a Gamdias Pad). Through practice and practice you can achieve amazing things and compete without a gamepad or building a swing rail(cheating in my opinion.). Now my in game handicap is at +9 and getting better(Just shot a 55 at Flathead).

You would think that if you played off a +9 you have mastered the game, but you would be mistaken. In elite tournaments playing on your handicap will only just get you in the top 50. Its all about the quest we as golfers share but never attain...Perfection.

The quest to be the best and the opportunity to really compete with thousands of other golfers is what makes the golfers club an amazing golf game.

Now to the game play. Is it perfect? No, there are problems, especially regarding the rules. With rules I refer to the lack of dropping in the game when you are unfortunate enough to land in a water hazard of end up in an unplayable lie. Most times the re-hit option is enforced only on a rare occasion does the game will drop for you. As for the unplayeble situation, it play it as it lies(or restart ;-) ) There is no custom drop option which is annoying.(They have rectified the droping problem with the last update!04/05/2015)

How do you become good? Swinging straight is only 10pecent of the battle. You really have to think about you shot: Club selection, Shot Type, Height, Shape and the most important part of all, where do you want to hit the next shot from. Especially when it comes to where you what to putt from. Speed and rythm of your swing is also very important. Don't think a fast back and through will do it or get you more distance.

The Golf Club is an Awsome golf game and I feel it is one of my best purchases on steam to date. I can't wait for the Seasons DLC to come out. No problem with buying it as a add on. I feel I have gotten more that my moneys worth so far.

Highly recommended!!!!! You get out what you put in just like in real life golf!

reviewText:
The Golf Club is a great idea. Place a golf sim game on the PC platform when other developers refuse to and give it a course creator. What could possibly go wrong with such a strong idea? Many things.

First and foremost this game does not run well. Even on powerful machines you will innevitably find yourself playing on Medium or lower settings just to get a decent and constant framerate. This is something that can be overlooked by many but still needs to be stated as it is important.

Ball striking is solid and good until you get close to the green. Due to the minimal control you have over shot distance anything other than a full 100% shot into the green is unlikely to land anywhere near where you intend it to. Putting is also a widely varying affair where getting correct distances is nearly impossible.

The course creator is one of the shining positives in The Golf Club. It has enough functionality and customization to allow for a large variety of course types and difficulties. However, more recent updates had altered some of the terrain functionality making it difficult to create smoothed surfaces with large scale changes. Still, the course creator is definitely a strong point.

The largest issue with this game currently is the seeming abandonment of the PC Platform. With their release on PS4 and XBox One, HB Studios have given continuous updates to both of the console platforms, yet have not updated the PC release with any of that content for 2 months as of this writing. ('Release was on October 8th, currently December 15th) This is the most diseheartening thing HB could have done. The console versions now have more HB created cources, 2 more course creator themes, and more bug fixes than the PC version.

With this last point in mind, I cannot recommend this game. It is a wonderful idea with a nice course creator that seems to have been abandoned before it could be made into something great. If you really want a golf game on the PC platform and have no other options then pick this up when it is on sale for 50% off or more, otherwise just steer clear. If they ever come back and give the PC platform some love, it may be worth the asking price, but as it stands it is not.

Edit: As of 12/19/2014 the PC and console versions are finally on the same patch. Going forward it is difficult to tell if they will become split so disparately as before but this does not change the core idea that it is better to wait for a sale for this game than to buy it at full price.

reviewText:
After many years of shelling out money for other golf games and then having to pay more for extra golf courses, I've finally found the ideal solution to my common peeve.  A course with a built-in creator.  There are thousands of courses to choose from.

The controls are similar  to the TW series from EA.  It's a game that you're going to struggle with at first, but as you keep playing and practicing, you will get much better.  There are no special power-ups, pants, or hats, just an equal playing field where the individuals that are the most skilled, shine.

The creator is accessible to everyone.  You can have it design the course for you and automatically generate a course based on some random parameters you enter.  Or you can start with a blank slate, place the 1st tee and green wherever you want and draw the fairway in between and then plant the bunkers.

The creator may seem daunting to some and they may find themselves intimidated by all the features and controls.  But there is an incredibly active community on the game website's forum http://www.hb-studios.com/forum/index.php#c7, and a well built community focused on competitive tournaments that are cross platform http://tgctours.com/

Best parts about this game is that it's constantly upgrading and improving.  If you had a look at this game when it was first released, take another look at it.  There have been dozens of major features added to the creator AND play modes with more on the way.  Also, if you ever have  problem, the developers and players are quick to answer questions and help you when you run into trouble.

This is a golf game you shouldn't ignore.

reviewText:
First off, if you are looking for a Tiger Woods replacement, then this may not be for you. The graphics are excellent on my laptop (i7 2.4, Geforce GT740 and 16g Ram) - smooth scrolling and sharp, clear detail. I found a controller the easiest / best way to play the game.

In my opinion, the game does not need a career mode as suggested by some players. Yes, it can be repetative, but so is the actual game of golf. There are currently in excess of 50,000 user created courses, some better than others. You can create your own course in five minutes if you like, or spend hours adjusting pretty much any aspect of each hole. Having access to user created courses, competitions and tours adds an extra dimension to The Golf Club that I have not come across in other golf games. I have no problem with the wind and find this fairly accurate, along with 'clubbing up or down' depending on the height of the green

The introduction of the Handicap system means you can continually try to lower your handicap on the handicap rated courses or simply play as many different courses as you want.

One thing I would like to see is a layout map of a course (like you get on the back of a scorecard) before I select to play it. Some more courses from the developers would also be good.........

Overall, the best golf game by far - no gimicks, just as much golf as you want. I can see why some may not like this game because of it's simplicity - if that is the case, get yourself an old copy of Tiger Woods :-)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

UPDATED 17/06/2015

I've been gaming since the '70s and I've played a lot of different games over that time on a lot of different systems.  But until now I've not known a games company support their product like HB have.  It is still receiving incredible updates; so much so that it is almost unrecognisable to the original release.

The game has swallowed my life.  Buy it.


ORIGINAL REVIEW BELOW

I've spent a lot of time with this game now and I'm looking forward to spending more time with it.

At the time of review, this game is in Early Release.  But you wouldn't know.  If you pay your money now then you are getting a highly polished game.  If you like golf, you'll love this.

The game itself is immensely addictive.  It is much more of a simulation compared to the nonsensical arcade style of Tiger Woods (Hit a good shot, penalised because you weren't wearing a Nike wristwatch?).

It is easy to hit a bad shot on this game and putting can be difficult.  But hit a good shot and you'll be rewarded - just like real golf.  And that is the point.  It *feels* like real golf.  You'll get frustrated at your bad shot 'cos you know you can do better.  You'll stop and think on each of your shots.  A good round of golf *feels* like a good round.  If you've played golf games in the past then you'll know how much of an achievement this is.  And I've been playing golf games since NIck Faldo Plays The Open came out on the Spectrum in 1985.

The course creator is a real gem.  It is a beautiful tool.  Take a look at the game's forums and see some of the creations that have been put down by the community.  Many people have spent 50 hours + on their work - and it shows.  But the real beauty is the simplicity of the tool.  You can create a beautiful course in no time at all - and with little effort.  But if you put a bit of effort in, then you and others will appreciate the results.

Proposed additions to the game will make this even better.  Frankly, this is a must buy for anyone with an interest in golf.  You won't be dissapointed.

reviewText:
This piece of art has tremendous potential. I am thankful to the developers for a lovely game where I can play a large amount of golf between writing mission critical code and working on my software developments (relaxation much). What makes this game excellent is:

1. The swing mechanic isn't newcomer friendly. The swing has a learning curve, you MUST pull your mouse backwards and then forwards to thrust your shots. This step done by you controlling your hand, wrist and arm need be precise for perfect shots otherwise you will inherit a large handicap. The handicap can be thought as a rank, the lower the handicap, the better your precision in this game I conclude.

The game plots a linear traversal of your mouse movement per shot, thus you can see if you need improve pulling back or pushing forward to maintain a straight swing of each club.

2. Each club is distinct, each has its own feel and each has a distinct difficulty to master.

3. The game is not arcade-like, it caters to a hardcore gamer. Thus it may be considered in time a golf variant eSports title, much like Counter Strike is to professional FPS players.

4. MAPS! The game includes real-world golf courses thus adding more realism. The game also includes algorithms so that, a) other players can create courses and upload them for other players to play and b) you can play a new course in literally seconds thus new content additions driven by the community for the community.

A sound financial investment for years of golf playing for those of us struck at our desk. Try it, when you get the hang of it, its fun.

---

Things I'd like to see in future.

1. Graphical Settings, I would like to tweak all settings, my computer is a beast and I want to see what is enabled when I've set the game launch settings to HIGH.

2. Frame Rendering when Window is Inactive. I play in windowed mode and not fullscreen, thus when I window switch to a work window, I want to be able to see frame updates in the game window (which is inactive) without having to click on it again. This is useful when in multiplayer, watching others play etc whilst I can write some more code inbetween my shots.

3. Customisation options, character customisation etc.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So, I've been mostly trying to stay away from early access games, particularly story driven games, which, in my opinion, are very ill suited for early access.  However certain types of games are well suited for early access, and sports games fall into that category.  Plus, I was really desperate for a golf game, so I took a chance and picked up The Golf Club.

This game has a ton of potential and is already in pretty decent shape, for something this far from being finished.  The game is very playable right now, even though many modes and features are missing, as is to be expected of an early access game.

I really enjoy the mechanics of the game.  This is not your standard 3 click fare.  I have yet to play with the mouse, but gamepad controls work really well.  You aim with the left thumbstick and swing with the righ, pulling back to wind up, then pushing up to swing.  Hitting standard full power shots is relatively straight forward.  Intentionally hitting a slice or hook to get around an obstacle, or doing a 3/4 swing is much much touchier and riskier, as it should be.  There is also less hand holding than in most golf games, which is great.  You need to figure out effects of wind and such on your own.

A highlight of the game is the course creation tool.  While it's missing some templates at the moment, as well as a lot of features, it;s already a really good and robust tool.  With a few parameters you enter the tool will procedurally generate a course in seconds, then you can tweak the course to your heart's content.  There are already hundreds of user made coursed published, some hastily slapped together or nonsensical, but many really beautiful and well made.

In conclusion, this game is already pretty good, and it will only get better from here on out.  I definitely recommend it to anyone looking for a golf game.

reviewText:
http://youtu.be/_ENz1NK4tQM

It's been quite some time since golf fans have been spoiled for choice. EA has dominated one of the worlds most regal games for more than a decade and those who play games on a PC in particular have been left with little to no choice in how they hit the links. Enter The Golf Club, a new Golf simulator from HB studios that doesn't boast PGA licensing or tons of product placement, but it does offer a massive game changing feature that is sure to land in the fairway with most virtual golfers: a course editor. Instead of shelling out absurd sums of money for new courses players now have access to a surprisingly robust course creation tool with Greg Norman's name slapped across it. So does The Golf Club burst on the scene like Tiger Woods circa 1997 or does it choke like Sergio Garcia on Sunday at a major?

Without PGA licensing, The Golf Club feels more like a virtual golf outing with friends than a tense and competitive sports simulation. There isn't a character creator, no RPG like leveling or character progression, no unlockables nor upgrades. The Golf Club also doesn't offer any alternative modes like challenges or mini games. You simply pick a course or a tournament and hit the links. Asynchronous play is generally the preferred play mode if you don't have good buddies available for eighteen since it allows brisk competitive play. Your competitors strokes are shown as you take your own and minimal load times keep the pace up and reduces the tedium present in other golf titles. A generic announcer provides the only semblance of professional golf tournament ambiance since galleries of spectators, scoreboards and tournament sponsor signs are all absent from the game's courses. The announcer does a decent job of reacting to your shots and making accurate assessments of the conditions on the course, but his personality is on par with a rusty, dinged-up pitching wedge. It's a shame that HB studios didn't utilize the freedom of not being a PGA licensed product to offer some more festive commentary a la Gary McCord at the 1994 Masters Tournament.

The Golf Club's bare bones feature set and lack of atmosphere and ambiance are not it's most prominent offense however, its the fact that the actual golf mechanics feel woefully underdeveloped. The game seems to favor a grip it and rip it mentality as any attempt I made to be clever with my shots ended in utter disaster with the exception of the instances in which the game decided to make some sort of idiotic club selection—teeing off on a par five with an 8-iron for instance. Speaking of club selection a clunky interface makes proper club selection tedious. Players must enter the scout camera mode to see where their ball may end up with a solid shot and if players wish to see where a different club might place the ball, the scout mode needs to be exited and a new club selection needs to be made. Spinning the ball or controlling draw or fade is slightly awkward with a shot modifier that needs to be dialed in before making a stroke. There is also very little feedback when trying to control the strength of your shots. Taking a few yards off of a stroke becomes an exercise in frustration since the difference between 70% and 100% power is a millimeter of travel on the analog stick and there are no meters or other visual indicators to allow players to get a feel for it. If there is another way to modify the strength of your shots I could not find it and a tutorial was not provided. The game's bare bones approach also means that you are stuck with a fixed club selection so don't expect to carry a hybrid or a long iron in place of your five wood.

Thankfully, the course editor in The Golf Club does not disappoint. Offering desert, links, alpine, rural and autum tile sets and a wide array of props, the course editor easily allows players to build realistic courses with few limitations. A number of sliders that populate the world with vegetation, water and hills automates some of the more tedious aspects of design. Bridges, wildlife, structures and props allow you to breathe life into each hole and imbue your course with some personality. Editing can be done hole by hole or freely across the entire course. Coupled with the game's mostly pleasing visuals it's exciting to turn your vision into a virtual reality and then share it with the world. It's just a shame that the frame rate can be slower than the senior tour—even on powerful hardware.

The Golf Club brings to mind all of those 1990's home designer software packages available in most electronics stores. Teeing off in The Golf Club is underwhelming but creating courses is any golf fan's dream. The actual golf is a bit clunky and in need of a swing coach with it's poor feedback, lack of club selection, and cumbersome UI. The lack of atmosphere and character progression do little to incentivize actually playing the game. While The Golf Club hasn't quite passed Q School, it's not entirely irredeemable. With so few choices for PC gamers, The Golf Club is worth considering for serious golf fans, those on consoles have a little more to consider but the course creator is quite compelling. In the end, The Golf Club logs a bogey on the score card.

reviewText:
Look at my hours played, well over 1000, so I can't possibly give this game a bad review. I love the game, but it's simplistic, basic, and lacks almost every option you can imagine. I am a casual video golfer, I want to hit most fairways, hit most of the greens and score better than par. It is pretty easy to do that in this game.

Read the reviews and System Requirements, this game renders the whole course at once, so no load times between holes, but you need a beefy pc to play it the way it was intended and you MUST have version 11 of Direct X

Pros/cons depending on how you look at it:

There are basically no options in this game, I don't really ever see many options in its future, it is just a simple golfgame where you can relax and play a round of golf like an average joe on the weekend.

Everyone uses the same clubs, you can only drive the ball about 270 yards without wind, but you will get wind as they won't give you the option to play without it.

The game currently has over 70 thousand user courses, but not easy searching for the ones you will enjoy playing.

The Greg Norman Course Creator is an awesome addition as I enjoy playing a different course every time I play, this is a good thing as very few courses warrant a second play.

No lobby for multiplayer, but you can play a friends ghost ball or play a live friend with almost real time results.

Putter - Putting feels great
Woods - driving is brainless, you can do it while argueing with the wife, if you can move the control stick backward and then forward you will be a star.
Irons - I like them
Chipping and Flops is probably way too easy for most hard core golf gamers.

Rating:
Gameplay - 7/10
Graphics - 7/10
Fun - 8/10
Golf Options to make this a great game. 2/10
Manual or ingame tutorial - None - 0/10
Optimized - Game runs on the Unity Engine, either the engine is weak or a bad choice to render whole course at once or their coders can't optimize it as they seem to dummy stuff down with each new addition, like the engine can't handle anymore or the code is running amok. 3/10

I guess this game is a buyer's beware game, you'll either love it or it will run like a 2 legged dog.

I really enjoy this game. Yes, I think it could be better with some freakin' Options, but that ain't gonna happen.

My overall rating would be 6.5, but I really enjoy this game and I have to play on medium with a Windows7 Home Premium, service pack 1, AMD FX 8120 Eight core processor, 3.10 Ghz, 8Gb Ram, 64bit OS, Nvidia Geforce GTX 560 2 GB card.

OK. Now go buy this game, but don't come running to me if it doesn't run on your PC. I am a glass half-empty type person so your mileage may vary.

reviewText:
First impressions after two hours:
A goodlooking golf game, with loads of courses to enjoy (some 30+)
A Seasons mode, which was the reason I bought THIS golf game, and which I am looking forward to (after more solo rounds for practice)
A commentary voice which does an excellent job AND with good timing (in older golf games the commentary would tell you that things were good or wrong when the ball had just left the ground!)
Fast and smooth loading of the next hole

The only thing sofar that strikes me as odd is the Follow camera. It only picks up halfway into flight, and sometimes flight is shown from the side (which I don't want). In recent years, most golf games (like Tiger Woods) follow the ball from the moment the club hits it, which gives a lot more visual excitement to a quite cerebral game. So I tried F12 to experiment with available Cam modes, only to find that the game gets confused and stuck, and options show weird POV's. After not being able to find my way back to my golfplayer, I have to go back to the main gamescreen and then choose Resume Game to return to a recognisable view. Not great.
I hope the developers will adress this issue...


Final words: interesting and good looking golf game!

reviewText:
As a golfer, this is the best PC golf game I have played.

Pros:
-Fast and firm greens for that PGA Tour feel
-Shot shaping works well
-Great power percentage system out of rough, sand, etc

Cons:
-Way too much spin on flop shots and very short pitches. Has the developer even played golf before?
-Not enough spin on short/mid iron shots. Again, watch the PGA Tour sometime.
-Wind is inconsistent. Can vary from 0 to 15mph on any course for some reason. Makes some rounds much easier than others.
-I wish there was a better way to discover new courses

reviewText:
Early Access Review

To be fair it's pretty much the only game in town in terms of PC golf sim since EA's execrable Tiger Woods The Masters debacle, and the good news is it's a thoroughly decent effort, easy to pick up and play, but with skills to master through ongoing play, nice to look at (although as a beta it's all in need of a final polish).  For an early access game it really is outstanding, by the time it reaches alpha and the community get to work with the course editor to produce some real world courses there may well be nothing to touch it on the PC or consoles.

Heartily recommended for anyone who still remembers Links fondly.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This review was inspired by some of the forum posts i have seen of late. Many are complaining that it's difficult, other's try to compare this to tiger woods. The biggest complaint is the fact that this game is difficult, it has not indication of where the ball will land, you cannot change your power on the swing as effectively as in every other golf game. There is no 3 click swing option either.

While these features are negatives for others, i find this brilliant. It's as close to a real golf game as can be. If you are a real golfer, you will know that golf, is part luck and part experience. In real golf you cannot really control the strenght of your swing, your golf club is designed for a set distance and momentum does the rest. You can adjust your stance and swing to give you an INeffective swing which is then called a chip, punch or a pitch. These types of swings are created by constraining the swing of the club. GC does the same. You cannot see where the ball is going to land IRL, you hope it's going to land where you want it to land, this is what GC does. It's not always possible to have a 100% power on swing in real life, this is what CG does.

Now if these are going to change, i would not know, but it sure as hell stops the above avarage scores from happening less than often. Along with the course designer, you will always have to think to play and not run in like a pro and finish 24 below par. The game has some performance issues and there are a few hiccups, hence the ALPHA state. There are however a few recommendations that will turn this into the best Golf game i have played to date. Having a stamina meter or the option to play randomly created golf courses of your friends will really make this one shine.

For those seeking something easier, run back to your Mario Golf or PGA tiger woods games and stay away from this one. This is golf....in digital form, so SUCK IT UP and welcome to the real golfer's world.

reviewText:
This game should not have mixed reviews as it has. It is an excellent game as it is today! Do not be fooled by the vague, one dimension of the game earns it a thumbs down" reviews. Here are some things you need to know before buying it so you do not harp on the game for one single thing.

This is a direct x 11 game. If you do not have a compatible graphics card that can play directx 11 games. do not buy this until you do. It says that under recommended hardware  andunder the bare requirements for the game.

This game is best played with a controller. It does its best attempt for smart control on a keyboard and mouse but having a controller is should be the standard for you to enjoy the game. This game does not hold your hand.  The game play is a simulation of real golf and this game is a simulator without the licensed pros.

They have put so much into the physics of the game that you have to account for the environment as much as the consistency of your fingers playing it. All these people calling it inconsistent are really just having a hard time being consistent operating the controls to the game. It is not the game making the mistakes! This game is unforgiving and if only with the added handicap does it love you. So if you get it
recommended:
and look at the tutorials on their website explaining golf physics and information in understanding their game. You would realize it was you all along. This is not a simple push a button to hit the ball sort of game.

It also does not display the line of trajectory before you hit. This at which I think is amazing. Do you see the line of trajectory of your golf ball before you drive or putt in real life? NO! Can you imagine how boring the leaderboards would be if they held your hand to the top. A popular game called Dark Souls is so popular because of how hard it is. This game is the golf version of that. It is hard and that is why it is fun and also fair.

Now with that there are a few things I hope change for the better to make this game even better with some suggeastions.
A little more selection in the appearance and attire including colors of the golfers and clothes would be nice.

I do not believe female characters tee off at the female tees. Not that they need to

reviewText: “I'm hitting the woods just great, but I'm having a terrible time getting out of them”. ~Harry Toscano\n\nThus an extremely accurate description of my own golf game in real life. Mates good naturedly sledging each other whilst playing a round at the local Golf Course is a strangely relaxing way to enjoy a day. Yep it is a game where “……….. you yell fore
date:
shoot six, and write down five”. ~Paul Harvey

No longer however, as HB Studio’s has recently released The Golf Club. This is a golf game based on that premise of it is you and your mates playing at your local golf club. There are no licensed courses, and strangely this makes little difference as there are more excellent courses than you will ever be able to play from the 1000’s already available.

When playing these courses you will feel like a virtual champion, even by scoring +2 or -8 and for the majority of virtual golfers this will probably be around your score. That is exactly what makes this game so good, yes you will hit drives straighter, but still have your shanks; you will still have some tricky approach shots which at times will make you feel like a hero and other times like you are playing real golf; and the putting in my opinion is the best that has ever been in a golf game. The amount of putts I just miss, genuinely makes me feel like I really am out on the golf course.

The graphics are of a very good quality, you will not be disappointed by the look of these courses, though be aware there are a very few, that could make your system of choice chug due to the amount of detail that has been added in. HB Studio’s were on to this quickly though and have now placed a cap on the amount of detail that can be added to prevent this, however there is still plenty of room to create your course rendition.

Yes, you have read between the lines well from the odd comments in the last few paragraphs. This golf game also comes with an extremely good course creator. How good, well the Greg Norman design company now use it as a design tool for their clients, and there are many superb user created courses, some of which can be seen here on my YouTube Channel;

https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLaQ9yFmYtTDa1Ln3hzklh6jeJMPz-m2uB

In conclusion this is a golf game no virtual golfer should be without in their collection. The course designer is worth the price of admission alone and well the game play itself;  “If I had cleared the trees and drove the green, it would’ve been a great shot ~ Sam Snead
recommended: will keep you coming back for round after virtual round."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Even from the start of The Golf Club's early access campaign, the player had access to one of the best golf engines on PC since the Tiger Woods franchise stopped being developed for computers. The swing system demands a controller, and if you read the forums, you will see that people trying to use a mouse and keyboard are quite sore over the current implementation.

However, with a controller (in my case, the XBox 360 controller for PC,) the swing system is incredibly intuitive and challenging! You never feel cheated off a bad swing, as the stick-based swing reads your pull back and push forward incredibly accurately, and if you fade or draw your shot, you know it was because you did not shoot a good shot! With an analogue stick controller, the swing system is the best, most challenging, but most rewarding golf simulation on PC right now.

Note, as a design choice, the developers have already said that they will never develop a 3-click system or a similiar power meter. They feel that their swing system is incredibly important to keeping the simulation feel of the game, and they think that a power-meter system will cheapen the game. Please make note of this, and do not buy this game, if you are expecting a Hot Shots Golf or Mario Golf type system!

Aethestically, the game is a bit lacking. The game does not have any real progression for your character - you can play rounds, tours, or other competitions of varying length and difficulty the moment you boot up the game. The challenge comes from the rounds that other players have finished, and you are competing against ghosts of their low scores. This can make the game feel a bit lonely, but they have slowly been adding more functionality in, such as the ability to play your friends live if you both play the same course, and you can even switch on a turn-based system to make it feel like the two (or three, or four) of you are alternating shots. The multiplayer feels a bit patched together and enough features are missing that it still feels a bit unprofessional, but ever since launch they have been fixing bugs and adding new content. Once full-stat tracking goes live, the game will become much more interesting as you challenge your friends in a variety of skills.

The game includes a full course editor, and this is incredibly important, as the game ships with only a few courses developed by the dev team. However, playin custom made courses is an absolute breeze. You can view player-made courses just as easily as the developer made ones, and a 0.0-10.0 rating system allows you to mark your favorite courses, and see which tee's the Golf Club community think are top notch. Already there is a wonderfully recreated version of Augusta National, and I'm sure more PGA-tour courses are going to be developed by the community.

This is very important as well, as this indie, small-studio game does not have the PGA tour license. There are no professional golfers at all in the game - it instead makes you feel like you are a club or amateur player getting their turns on a huge variety of courses set in a huge variety of difficulty levels. As you get better you can choose to play near impossible courses where the fairways are narrow strips of land between two lakes, or you can choose to hone your short-approach and pitching skills on a variety of par 3 courses.

As more high quality replications of real life golf courses are added to the game, you will begin to see a product that more closely resembles the Tiger Woods games of the past. I read that this indie studio was originally contracted out to make the analog-swing stick system for previous Tiger Woods games, and their pedigree at making an incredibly well rounded golf engine shows. However, you can also see that they have very little experience creating the rest of the product. The UI is very minimal, the announcer volume is best turned to 0 after a round or two, and there is almost no flash or style in the presentation itself.

Despite this, there are many other benefits than just the solid swing system. There is no loading time between holes once you load the entire course. Like real life, you can see the other holes around you when you're on the course, and as soon as the ball rolls into the pin, you are onto your next drive. They recently made shot adjustments more challenging - in early versions of the game, it would tell you exactly how many feet you were adding onto or off your shot by changing the angle of your shot higher or lower. Now, it only shows a percentage of your full shot power, making the system more challenging and realistic.

In the future, I would love to see some official branding, such as official golf clubs, clothing, and other gear. However, I know it is an indie studio, and at the end of the day, they have made an incredibly well rounded golf SIMULATION that is absolutely terrific at doing what it advertises - letting you experience rounds of golf on a near-endless supply of courses. The developers have been constantly tweaking, refining, patching, and adding new content into the game since its early access launch, and despite a few early stumbles, the game seems to be well on its way to being the best golf simulation on PC.

If you liked the Tiger Woods games, or if you think you would enjoy a golf game that challenges you to be perfect nearly every shot, like the game does in real life, this is a must-buy for you! Golf fans, please do not sleep on this purchase simply because it doesn't have the pomp that EA golf games have. As the community adds more high quality content and the developers further refine the game, this has the potential to be a long lasting success!

As of July 19th, I rate this game an 8.1/10.0
Go buy it; I need more friends to compete with!!!

reviewText:
Graphics are brilliant and it's very atmospheric (geese swimming on the water, rabbits running around, birds singing, etc)

I use an Xbox 360 controller for windows and the swing with the right joystick feels good and I find it reasonably easy to control. The straighter you move the stick backwards and forwards, the straighter your shot. The putting takes a bit of getting used to, but after a while you get a feel for it, just like real golf.

You can also enter tournaments which other players online play in and there is a season mode, which is a DLC which has various difficulties which you unlock by completing the one before.

I'd really like them to have put in a driving range and putting green option for practicing, but other than that the game is brilliant.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'm playing the Early Access version of The Golf Club. What can i say? it plays a very good round of Golf!  Graphically there are obvious similarites to a certain game featuring The Tiger... but thats where it stops. ( same team see )

This is more about a relaxing game of golf, than all those tiresome silly special moves etc.
I also really  like the stand in commentator on this early access version!
I believe its one of the developers doing the witty commentary. You should go with him but give him a script! in the finished version.

The course content is phenomenal, due to everyone creating courses in the creator. Even if the licence was not available  or the actual real life  course is not in the game, theres always one been created by the community thats very similar.  Online multiplayer , ghosts and leaderboards are all there too. This is going to be such a great game.

The early access version is excellent as it is! so i expect good things when its released everywhere soon. The consoles are getting this game as well. And they do say that all created courses are available to play, on whatever version of the game you own!  so if i made a course on the PC, a console owner could play on it too. Exciting stuff indeed!

It reminds me of Tiger crossed with Links Golf.

My chosen control method is an Xbox 360 pad by the way. Works very well!

reviewText:
A faltering yes.  In regard to PC it is still hard to go past PGA 2008, and The Golf Club unfortunately does not exceed that 6 year old package.

Positives : Equal playing field. No body gets exclusive equipment, putt previews and all that cash content that ruined EA's PGA On line. The swing and putt mechanism are fairly good, and without previews the game is  harder than the last PGA offer.

Negatives: Has the feel that it was once intended to be the package to end all packages, then was banadoned, only to be picked up and released with what we have to date".

Like PGA it is a brag session for good players
date: the scorecards does not list other players at my skill
recommended: only the elite. A handicap system would be nice. In trying to implement a  course desginer that works with the dreaded consoles  it has ended up crippling a useful PC one. I am still yet to play with a "live " player. The graphics are jerky on a PC. Full HD?  looks no better than past TW PGA releases.\n\nAll up the price is right
hoursPlayed: but do not expect cutting edge."

reviewText:
Vitality’s S&T ReviewsShort and Tasty… The Bits that matter



Short Story
Get your score cards out because this is a HOLE-IN-ONE!

Overview
The Golf Club is a golf simulation video game developed by HB Studios on the Unity game engine. It is a golf sim, boasting a powerful Course Creator based on the procedural generation of courses. The Course Creator can generate a brand new course in seconds which can be shared and played immediately online with friends and other gamers.

Vitality’s Thoughts
These mixed reviews are SERIOUSLY insane! I was very hesitant on actually purchasing, But boy am I glad I did.

I'm coming from Tiger Woods 08, And I seamlessly transferred into this modern take on the sport without any issues.

People complain about the putting, but again I have no problem with it. Yes it takes getting used too, but come on this is a GOLF simulator, People realise how FRUSTRATING this game can be right ?

There's a few negatives I do have with it though, When I play 4 player game modes and we create and edit the player names I would like the system to remember the names I've set for them and there outfits, So We don't have to customise them every few days we are going to be playing. Right now it just defaults them to (Name_1) not the name I've set for them.

I also wish I could disable the ball following lines, and also speed up the ball when in mid flight.

This game IS GOOD though, I don't think it's exactly worth the $40 price tag, and the way they sell stuff can be a little dodgy, as the season mode is a paid DLC but they're minor, If you can get the game for under $30 it's well worth it.

Pros:  Amazing Graphics, Wildlife, And Plants
Great Simulation of a frustrating sport
Course creation is amazing, You'll never get bored playing the same 10 courses
The Commentator isn't generic and annoying like most games
Won't cost you $50 for a pack of real balls to lose in the creek Cons:  Player Customisation is limiting
4 Player mode should save custom players
Some HUD options for lines etc would be nice
Pricing is a little dumb founding. (I believe in DLC, But for Season mode?) Conclusion
Great golf simulator, Probably the best on the market right now, I would highly recommend the game to any avid golfer or anyone who wants to play a golf sim, Don't look at the game though if you're after an arcade Tiger woods though. I'd also recommend the game be purchased under $30, But if you've got the money you won't be  disappointed.

79/100
voteText: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is agreeably the best Golfing game there could ever be. This game truly brings a sense of realism like no other golfing game ever has. This is the only true Golf Simulator in the world; and quite possibly one of the most visually stunning simulators of nature available.

This simulator truly deserves credit for how stunning, intuitive and downright perfect the controls for not only KB/Mouse but Controllers as well. Hopefully the graphics can be pushed even farther in the future, as the quality of them right now is just purely perfect (other than the obvious early access visual bugs).

So my rating, 10/10. Absolutely perfect in what is offered.
I'm sure with what's planned in the future, it will become much much more worth it.
voteText: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
A quick history about me and golf games; I've been interested and played golf games since the early LINKS series on DOS/Windows, as well as Tiger Woods, and other iterations throughout the years. I haven't played a game on the PC in years, and purchased this game during the Early Access period.

First impressions! Beautiful landscapes, variety of enviroments, endless courses to play (thanks to generation and community games), native controller support, Couch COOP and online modes! The feature set is impressive, and the controls seem natural and well thought out. It's an easy game to get into, but a tough game to master, exactly like golf. :) Playing online with friends is a bit different, as you are set to play simultaneously on the same course by default. You can however, change it to 'Alternate Shot' by a quick visit to the menu. No relog required.

Some nice changes I'd like to see! I'd like to see more variety in the player creation (more clothing options, more customizability), as well as customized clubs or bags for an added touch. These would be flavour items only, and provide no additional benefits (as the game is designed). The game could also benefit from a bit of an easier way to join friends games, such as using the Steam Menu 'Join Game'.

Summary - A beautifully designed, well executed golf game, with procedural course design and an endless pool of community talent, this may be the best golf game ever released on PC. Score - [ 9.5 / 10 ]

TLDR; Love golf games? Buy this now.

reviewText:
Jacko Rating
8.5/10  Collectors Edition Bundle
The best golf game to hit the PC in a long time.  The Golf Club kicks off where the last of the good golf sims left off - probably Tiger Woods franchise in my eyes.
The physics and feel of playing the game is spot on and I found myself loving the gameplay within minutes.  Graphics are some of the best I have seen for golf games, audio is good but the commentary is an absolute treat!  From the witty remarks and subtle hints at conditions the delivery and tone of the commentator is perfect and only wish we could have more of it.
Numerous options for games such as Teamball etc and Tournements plus Seasons gives you a career progression if you wish or you can just pick a course that you fancy and swing away.
Playing multi player works fine and there are several options to fiddle with if you want to watch each shot that your mates take or just move ahead and get on with the round.
The biggest win for this game is definately the amount of courses that are on offer, apart from the dozens of official ones form the developer there are literally thousands of courses that have been made by the community with the Greg Norman Golf Course Designer which is included in the Collectors Edition, some of which are better than the official ones.  Only negatives are the lack of customisable equipment such as choosing or upgrading clubs, balls etc.  You can change the clothes of your golfer but thats about it.
Hands down the best golf sim out there for PC at the momnet and I also have Perfect Golf - the best competition for this at the moment but by no means is it even close to the polished product The Golf Club has become.
Great game and a great community follwoing makes this a smart purchase at anytime.
voteText: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful

reviewText: I currently have purchased this game 3 different times for myself. The first time was on Xbox One. Loved it so much I had to purchase it for my Playstation 4. Played the game countless times. As I've continued gaming on the PC I purchased it through steam and still continue to play this game. If I had to buy it again I would without question. This isn't some ♥♥♥♥♥♥ unrealistic game like the tiger woods franchise. This is as simulated as it gets to real golf and I love it. If you want to control the golf ball in mid air, don't buy this game. If you want the feel of the real thing, spend the little money and enjoy.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Early Access Review (in progress)
This was the first game I ever bought from Early Access and it was worth every penny even in it's unfinished state.
While polish and adjustments are still being made as it stands now it's already better than almost any other golf game I have played. Couple that with an amazing course editor and we just might have the best golf game ever created.

This review is incomplete as the game is still incomplete and I don't want to take anything away from it with negatives that will more than likely get fixed as the development process continues till release. As it stands right now there isn't much in the way of features or modes other than the course creator and being able to play against other players ghosts (I find this feature annoying and usually always turn it off).

I would like to see more graphics-type updates and/or options. Some sort of career and more custimization of your character would be nice too. Other than these (minor) gripes I think it's great. It seems like every time I boot up the game there has been an update. These folks are not messing around and seem to really want to deliver the best product possible. I can't wait to see how the final product turns out.

reviewText:
Overall a good and challenging game, but there are a few glaring issues i feel need to be addressed.

First in my mind is courses with trees.  Golf is an ourdoor game, and trees make for great challenges and good looking courses, but the game's AI tends to place them extremely poorly..... Such as in the middle of the fairway, immediately in front of the tee block, and most hilariously on the greens.

Next up would be the coding for Fairway/Rough/Deep Rough/OMG WHY.  The colors of the terrain are a good indicator, but the game doesn't exactly follow them.... For instance i landed in the deep rough, bad me... Wait.... It thinks i'm hitting out of water?..... 58-68%, alright, i'll compensate..... swing... and 10 yards.

Finally (and MOST aggrevating), putting.  The putting mechanics seem to scale your put based on distance, and from long range you have two options, 15feet short or 20 feet long.... But as you get closer the opposite happens.  I don't know how many 1 foor puts i've missed, sometimes three in a row.... Simply because the game thinks one foot away you still need almost a half swing.... Which in any other situation on the green will leave you 16 feet past.

I've yet to determine what the difficulty on couses really means (i'm assuming tighter swing control since the red band view following shots is more narrow on difficult courses).

All in all a promising game, i hope it makes it to production and final distribution.... Though if you're looking to score -13 on every round, this game will be extremely frustrating.  As for the putting mechanics........ Just eagle it from 150yards out and save yourself the headache.

reviewText: It's graphically really nice, the course designer is really cool... but the gameplay is fairly boring and a little frustrating.  It's difficult to judge shots that aren't full shots, theres' no meter to show  your swing power, it seems like shot shape is totally determined by mouse movement tempo... get a little quick and you'll be hooking  your way around the course.  Tournament play is dull, I've only ever played ghost" players.  There's no storyline style of play w/ some sort of career path or tour path.  There's no variety of equipment or ability to maybe get some "boost" going from an amatuer to say a pro where you swing a little faster and get more distance
date: etc.  Overall it's not fun enough to hold my attention for more than about 10 mins at a time unless you're designing a course and then you can spend hours tweaking it (which sadly I have) and I probably won't play it much in the future."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you're a golf nut, this is the game for you.

It plays more like a round of golf on the weekend with some mates than anything else. The distinct and intended lack of gauges and meters makes the player more dependent on feel and instinct rather than calculated distances and angles. It's really well done. The proceedural course generation is reasonable, but there are a ton of high quality user made courses already online for unlimited play.

The only drawbacks for me at the moment are mainly confined to the UI. Lack of sorting options for players and courses, unacceptably long delays in ratings and scores going live, and some optimisation issues for PC.

Highly recommended.

8/10
